body.p: “Asked a sailor at the wharf how he distinguished a whaler. He said by the “davits “,”” large upright timbers with sheaves curving over the sides “,” thus: [image] to hold up the boats (a merchantman has only a few and small at the stern); also by the place for the man to stand at masthead (crosstree “,” I should say they were) and look out for whales “,” which you do not see on a merchant-ship; i.e. “,” the crosstrees of the latter are very slight “,” of the whaler somewhat like this: [image]
PE 14, pg. 367/ 9 November 1858-7 April 1859 / NNPM MA 1302:34 / T vol. # XXVIII / PDF # XVII / JXI
